com.stormpath.sdk.application

Interface Application

  • All Superinterfaces:
    Deletable, Resource, Saveable

    public interface Application
extends Resource, Saveable, Deletable
    An Application instance represents a Stormpath registered application.
    Since:
    0.1

        Returns the application's status. Application users may login to an enabled application. They may not login to a disabled application.

      • getAccounts

        AccountList getAccounts()
        Returns a paginated list of all accounts that may login to the application.

        Tip: Instead of iterating over all accounts, it might be more convenient (and practical) to execute a search for one or more accounts using the getAccounts(com.stormpath.sdk.account.AccountCriteria) or getAccounts(java.util.Map) methods instead of this one.

        Returns:
        a paginated list of all accounts that may login to the application.
        See Also:
        getAccounts(com.stormpath.sdk.account.AccountCriteria), getAccounts(java.util.Map)

      • getAccounts

        AccountList getAccounts(Map<String,Object> queryParams)
        Returns a paginated list of the accounts that may login to the application that also match the specified query criteria.

        Each queryParams key/value pair will be converted to String name to String value pairs and appended to the resource URL as query parameters, for example: 

         .../applications/applicationId/accounts?param1=value1¶m2=value2&...
        Parameters:
        queryParams - the query parameters to use when performing a request to the collection.
        Returns:
        a paginated list of the application's accounts that match the specified query criteria.
        Since:
        0.8

      • getAccounts

        AccountList getAccounts(AccountCriteria criteria)
        Returns a paginated list of the accounts that may login to the application that also match the specified query criteria. The Accounts utility class is available to help construct the criteria DSL. For example: 
         application.getAccounts(Accounts
     .where(Accounts.surname().containsIgnoreCase("Smith"))
     .and(Accounts.givenName().eqIgnoreCase("John"))
     .orderBySurname().descending()
     .withGroups(10, 10)
     .offsetBy(20)
     .limitTo(25));
        or, if using static imports: 
         import static com.stormpath.sdk.account.Accounts.*;

 ...

 application.getAccounts(where(
     surname().containsIgnoreCase("Smith"))
     .and(givenName().eqIgnoreCase("John"))
     .orderBySurname().descending()
     .withGroups(10, 10)
     .offsetBy(20)
     .limitTo(25));
        Parameters:
        criteria - the criteria to use when performing a request to the collection.
        Returns:
        a paginated list of the application's accounts that match the specified query criteria.
        Since:
        0.8

      • createAccount

        Account createAccount(Account account)
                      throws ResourceException
        Creates a new Account that may login to this application.

        This is mostly a convenience method; it delegates creation to the Application's designated defaultAccountStore, and functions as follows:

        • If the defaultAccountStore is a Directory: the account is created in the Directory and returned.
        • If the defaultAccountStore is a Group: the account is created in the Group's Directory, assigned to the Group, and then returned.

        Parameters:
        account - the account to create/persist
        Returns:
        a new Account that may login to this application.
        Throws:
        ResourceException - if the Application does not have a designated defaultAccountStore or if the designated defaultAccountStore does not allow new accounts to be created.
        Since:
        0.9

      • createAccount

        Account createAccount(CreateAccountRequest request)
                      throws ResourceException
        Creates a new Account that may login to this application according to the request criteria.

        This is mostly a convenience method; it delegates creation to the Application's designated defaultAccountStore, and functions as follows:

        • If the defaultAccountStore is a Directory: the account is created in the Directory and returned.
        • If the defaultAccountStore is a Group: the account is created in the Group's Directory, assigned to the Group, and then returned.

        Example

         application.createAccount(Accounts.newCreateRequestFor(account).build());

        If you would like to force disabling the backing directory's account registration workflow: 

         application.createAccount(Accounts.newCreateRequestFor(account).setRegistrationWorkflowEnabled(false).build());
        If you would like to force the execution of the registration workflow, no matter what the backing directory configuration is: 
         application.createAccount(Accounts.newCreateRequestFor(account).setRegistrationWorkflowEnabled(true).build());
        If you would like to retrieve the account's custom data in the response of the account creation. 
         application.createAccount(Accounts.newCreateRequestFor(account).withResponseOptions(Accounts.options().withCustomData()).build());

        Parameters:
        request - the account creation request
        Returns:
        a new Account that may login to this application.
        Throws:
        ResourceException - if the Application does not have a designated defaultAccountStore or if the designated defaultAccountStore does not allow new accounts to be created.
        Since:
        0.9

      • getGroups

        GroupList getGroups()
        Returns all Groups accessible to the application (based on the Application's associated Account stores).

        Tip: Instead of iterating over all groups, it might be more convenient (and practical) to execute a search for one or more groups using the getGroups(java.util.Map) method instead of this one.

        Returns:
        all Groups accessible to the application (based on the Application's associated Account stores).
        Since:
        0.8
        See Also:
        getGroups(java.util.Map)

      • getGroups

        GroupList getGroups(Map<String,Object> queryParams)
        Returns a paginated list of the groups accessible to the application (based on the app's mapped Account stores) that also match the specified query criteria.

        Each queryParams key/value pair will be converted to String name to String value pairs and appended to the resource URL as query parameters, for example: 

         .../applications/applicationId/groups?param1=value1¶m2=value2&...
        Parameters:
        queryParams - the query parameters to use when performing a request to the collection.
        Returns:
        a paginated list of the application's groups that match the specified query criteria.
        Since:
        0.8

      • getGroups

        GroupList getGroups(GroupCriteria criteria)
        Returns a paginated list of the groups accessible to the application (based on the app's mapped Account stores) that also match the specified query criteria. The Groups utility class is available to help construct the criteria DSL. For example: 
         application.getGroups(Groups
     .where(Groups.description().containsIgnoreCase("foo"))
     .and(Groups.name().startsWithIgnoreCase("bar"))
     .orderByName().descending()
     .withAccounts(10, 10)
     .offsetBy(20)
     .limitTo(25));
        or, if using static imports: 
         import static com.stormpath.sdk.group.Groups.*;

 ...

 application.getGroups(where(
     description().containsIgnoreCase("foo"))
     .and(name().startsWithIgnoreCase("bar"))
     .orderByName().descending()
     .withAccounts(10, 10)
     .offsetBy(20)
     .limitTo(25));
        Parameters:
        criteria - the criteria to use when performing a request to the collection.
        Returns:
        a paginated list of the application's accessible groups that match the specified query criteria.
        Since:
        0.8

      • sendPasswordResetEmail

        Account sendPasswordResetEmail(String email)
        Sends a password reset email for the specified account email address. The email will contain a password reset link that the user can click or copy into their browser address bar.

        This method merely sends the password reset email that contains the link and nothing else. You will need to handle the link requests and then reset the account's password as described in the verifyPasswordResetToken(String) JavaDoc.

        Parameters:
        email - an email address of an Account that may login to the application.
        Returns:
        the account corresponding to the specified email address.
        See Also:
        verifyPasswordResetToken(String), resetPassword(String, String)

      • verifyPasswordResetToken

        Account verifyPasswordResetToken(String token)
        Verifies a password reset token in a user-clicked link within an email.

        Base Link Configuration

        You need to define the Base link that will process HTTP requests when users click the link in the email as part of your Application's Workflow Configuration within the Stormpath UI Console. It must be a URL served by your application's web servers. For example: 
         https://www.myApplication.com/passwordReset

        Runtime Link Processing

        When an application user clicks on the link in the email at runtime, your web server needs to process the request and look for an spToken request parameter. You can then verify the spToken, and then finally change the Account's password.

        Usage Example:

        Browser: GET https://www.myApplication/passwordReset?spToken=someTokenValueHere

        Your code: 

         String token = httpServletRequest.getParameter("sptoken");

 Account account = application.verifyPasswordResetToken(token);

 //token has been verified - now set the new password with what the end-user submits:
 account.setPassword(user_submitted_new_password);
 account.save();
        Parameters:
        token - the verification token, usually obtained as a request parameter by your application.
        Returns:
        the Account matching the specified token.
        Since:
        0.4

      • resetPassword

        Account resetPassword(String passwordResetToken,
                    String newPassword)
        Verifies the password reset token (received in the user's email) and immediately changes the password in the same request (if the token is valid).

        NOTE: Once the token has been successfully used, it is immediately invalidated and can't be used again. If you need to change the password again, you will previously need to execute sendPasswordResetEmail(String) again in order to obtain a new password reset token.

        Parameters:
        passwordResetToken - the verification token, usually obtained as a request parameter by your application.
        newPassword - the new password that will be set to the Account if the token is successfully validated.
        Returns:
        the Account matching the specified token.
        Since:
        1.0.RC
        See Also:
        sendPasswordResetEmail(String)

      • authenticateAccount

        AuthenticationResult authenticateAccount(AuthenticationRequest request)
                                         throws ResourceException
        Authenticates an account's submitted principals and credentials (e.g. username and password). The account must be in one of the Application's assigned account stores. If not in an assigned account store, the authentication attempt will fail.

        Example

        Consider the following username/password-based example: 

         AuthenticationRequest request = new UsernamePasswordRequest(email, submittedRawPlaintextPassword);
 Account authenticated = appToTest.authenticateAccount(request).getAccount();
        Parameters:
        request - the authentication request representing an account's principals and credentials (e.g. username/password) used to verify their identity.
        Returns:
        the result of the authentication. The authenticated account can be obtained from result.getAccount().
        Throws:
        ResourceException - if the authentication attempt fails.

      • getAccount

        ProviderAccountResult getAccount(ProviderAccountRequest request)
        Retrieves a Provider-based Account. The account must exist in one of the Provider-based Directories assigned to the Application as an account store, the Directory must also be Enabled. If not in an assigned account store, the retrieval attempt will fail.

        Example

        Consider the following example: 

         ProviderAccountRequest request = Providers.GOOGLE.account()
                  .setCode("4/mV9k80PpUB7XK_2RvOqOkNrI7I8C.krFm0WYFM_sY3pEBd8D1tNHT8u6jiwI")
                  .build();
 ProviderAccountResult result = application.getAccount(request);
 Account account = result.getAccount();
        Parameters:
        request - the ProviderAccountRequest representing the Provider-specific account access data (e.g. accessToken) used to verify the identity.
        Returns:
        the result of the access request. The Account can be obtained from result.getAccount().
        Throws:
        ResourceException - if the access attempt fails.
        Since:
        1.0.beta

        Returns:
        all AccountStoreMappings accessible to the application.

      • getAccountStoreMappings

        AccountStoreMappingList getAccountStoreMappings(Map<String,Object> queryParams)
        Returns a paginated list of the application's mapped Account stores that also match the specified query criteria.

        Each queryParams key/value pair will be converted to String name to String value pairs and appended to the resource URL as query parameters, for example: 

         .../applications/applicationId/accountStoreMappings?param1=value1¶m2=value2&...

        This is a type-unsafe alternative to the getAccountStoreMappings(accountStoreMappingCriteria) method, and might be useful when using dynamic languages like Groovy or JRuby. Users of compiled languages, or those that like IDE-completion, might favor the type-safe method instead.

        Parameters:
        queryParams - the query parameters to use when performing a request to the collection.
        Returns:
        a paginated list of the application's mapped account stores that match the specified query criteria.
        Since:
        0.9
        See Also:
        getAccountStoreMappings(AccountStoreMappingCriteria)

         application.getAccountStoreMappings(AccountStoreMappings.criteria()
     .withAccountStore()
     .orderByListIndex();
        or, if using static imports: 
         import static com.stormpath.sdk.account.AccountStoreMappings.*;

 ...

 application.getAccountStoreMappings(criteria()
     .withAccountStore()
     .orderByListIndex();
        Parameters:

        Returns:
        a paginated list of the application's mapped account stores that match the specified query criteria.
        Since:
        0.9

      • getDefaultAccountStore

        AccountStore getDefaultAccountStore()
        Returns the AccountStore (either a Group or a Directory) used to persist new accounts created by the Application, or null if no accountStore has been designated.

        Because an Application is not an AccountStore itself, it delegates to a Group or Directory when creating accounts; this method returns the AccountStore to which the Application delegates new account persistence.

        Directory or Group?

        As both Group and Directory are sub-interfaces of AccountStore, you can determine which of the two is returned by using the Visitor design pattern. For example: 

         AccountStore accountStore = application.getDefaultAccountStore();
 accountStore.accept(new AccountStoreVisitor() {

     public void visit(Directory directory) {
         //the accountStore is a Directory
     }

     public void visit(Group group) {
         //the accountStore is a Group;
     }
 };

        Setting the 'New Account Store'

        You may set the defaultAccountStore by acquiring one of the Application's accountStoreMappings and calling setDefaultAccountStore(true) or by calling setDefaultAccountStore(com.stormpath.sdk.directory.AccountStore)
        Returns:
        the AccountStore (which will be either a Group or Directory) used to persist new accounts created by the Application, or null if no accountStore has been designated.
        Since:
        0.9

      • setDefaultAccountStore

        void setDefaultAccountStore(AccountStore accountStore)
        Sets the AccountStore (either a Group or a Directory) used to persist new accounts created by the Application.

        Because an Application is not an AccountStore itself, it delegates to a Group or Directory when creating accounts; this method sets the AccountStore to which the Application delegates new account persistence. Usage Notice: Unlike other methods in this class that require the Saveable.save() method to be called to persist changes, this is a convenience method will call the server immediately.

        Parameters:
        accountStore - the AccountStore (which will be either a Group or Directory) used to persist new accounts created by the Application

      • getDefaultGroupStore

        AccountStore getDefaultGroupStore()
        Returns the AccountStore used to persist new groups created by the Application, or null if no accountStore has been designated. Stormpath's current REST API requires this to be a Directory. However, this could be a Group in the future, so do not assume it is always a Directory if you want your code to be function correctly if/when this support is added. Avoid casting the returned value directly to a Directory: use the Visitor pattern as explained below.

        Because an Application is not an AccountStore itself, it delegates to a Directory (or maybe a Group in the future) when creating groups; this method returns the AccountStore to which the Application delegates new group persistence.

        Directory or Group?

        As both Group and Directory are sub-interfaces of AccountStore, you can determine which of the two is returned by using the Visitor design pattern. For example: 

         AccountStore groupStore = application.getDefaultGroupStore();
 groupStore.accept(new AccountStoreVisitor() {

     public void visit(Directory directory) {
         //groupStore is a Directory
     }

     public void visit(Group group) {
         //groupStore is a Group;
     }
 };
        Again, in practice, Stormpath's current REST API requires this to be a Directory. However, this could be a Group in the future, so do not assume it will always be a Directory if you want your code to be forward compatible; use the Visitor pattern and do not cast directly to a Directory.

        Setting the 'New Group Store'

        You set the newGroupStore by acquiring one of the Application's accountStoreMappings and calling setDefaultGroupStore(true) or by calling setDefaultGroupStore(com.stormpath.sdk.directory.AccountStore).
        Returns:
        the AccountStore (which will be either a Group or Directory) used to persist new groups created by the Application, or null if no accountStore has been designated.
        Since:
        0.9

      • setDefaultGroupStore

        void setDefaultGroupStore(AccountStore accountStore)
        Sets the AccountStore (a Directory) that will be used to persist new groups created by the Application. Stormpath's current REST API requires this to be a Directory. However, this could be a Group in the future, so do not assume it is always a Directory if you want your code to be function correctly if/when this support is added.

        Because an Application is not an AccountStore itself, it delegates to a Group or Directory when creating groups; this method sets the AccountStore to which the Application delegates new group persistence. Usage Notice: Unlike other methods in this class that require the Saveable.save() method to be called to persist changes, this is a convenience method will call the server immediately.

        Parameters:
        accountStore - the AccountStore (which will be either a Group or Directory) used to persist new groups created by the Application

      • createAccountStoreMapping

        AccountStoreMapping createAccountStoreMapping(AccountStoreMapping mapping)
                                              throws ResourceException
        Creates a new AccountStoreMapping for this Application, allowing the associated accountStore to be used as a source of accounts that may login to the Application.

        Usage Notice: Unlike other methods in this class that require the Saveable.save() method to be called to persist changes, this is a convenience method will call the server immediately.

        Authentication Process and AccountStoreMapping Order

        During an authentication attempt, an Application consults its mapped account stores in iteration order, trying to find the first matching account to use for authentication. The lower the AccountStoreMapping index (closer to zero), the earlier that store is consulted during authentication. If no matching account is found in an account store, the application will move on to the next AccountStore (next highest index) in the list. This continues either a matching account is found, or until all account stores are exhausted. When a matching account is found, the process is short-circuited and the discovered account will be used immediately for authentication.

        When calling this method, you control where the new AccountStoreMapping will reside in the Application's overall list by setting its (zero-based) listIndex property before calling this method.

        listIndex values

        • negative: attempting to set a negative listIndex will cause an Error
        • zero: the account store mapping will be the first item in the list (and therefore consulted first during the authentication process).
        • positive: the account store mapping will be inserted at that index. Because list indices are zero-based, the account store will be in the list at position listIndex - 1.
        Any listIndex value equal to or greater than the current list size will automatically append the AccountStoreMapping at the end of the list.

        Example

        Setting a new AccountStoreMapping's listIndex to 500 and then adding the mapping to an application with an existing 3-item list will automatically save the AccountStoreMapping at the end of the list and set its listIndex value to 3 (items at index 0, 1, 2 were the original items, the new fourth item will be at index 3). 
         AccountStore directoryOrGroup = getDirectoryOrGroupYouWantToUseForLogin();
 AccountStoreMapping mapping = client.instantiate(AccountStoreMapping.class);
 mapping.setAccountStore(directoryOrGroup);
 mapping.setListIndex(3); //this is zero-based, so index 3 == 4th item
 mapping = application.createAccountStoreMapping(mapping);
        Then, when authenticating an account, this AccountStore (directory or group) will be consulted if no others before it in the list found a matching account.

        New Account Storage

        If createAccount(com.stormpath.sdk.account.Account)
        Parameters:
        mapping - the new AccountStoreMapping resource to add to the Application's AccountStoreMapping list.
        Returns:
        the newly created AccountStoreMapping instance.
        Throws:
        ResourceException
        Since:
        0.9

      • addAccountStore

        AccountStoreMapping addAccountStore(AccountStore accountStore)
                                    throws ResourceException
        Creates a new AccountStoreMapping for this Application and appends that AccountStoreMapping to the end of the Application's AccountStoreMapping list, allowing the associated accountStore to be used as a source of accounts that may login to the Application.

        Usage Notice: Unlike other methods in this class that require the Saveable.save() method to be called to persist changes, this is a convenience method will call the server immediately.

        Authentication Process and AccountStoreMapping Order

        During an authentication attempt, an Application consults its mapped account stores in iteration order, trying to find the first matching account to use for authentication. The lower the AccountStoreMapping index (closer to zero), the earlier that store is consulted during authentication. If no matching account is found in an account store, the application will move on to the next AccountStore (next highest index) in the list. This continues either a matching account is found, or until all account stores are exhausted. When a matching account is found, the process is short-circuited and the discovered account will be used immediately for authentication.

        When calling this method, you are setting the new AccountStoreMapping to the end of the Application's overall list.

        NOTE: If you already know the account store where the account resides, you can specify it at the time the authentication request is created (for example, UsernamePasswordRequest.UsernamePasswordRequest(String, char[], com.stormpath.sdk.directory.AccountStore)). This way you will be avoiding the authentication attempt to cycle through the Application's account stores.

        Example

         AccountStore directoryOrGroup = getDirectoryOrGroupYouWantToUseForLogin();
 AccountStoreMapping mapping = application.addAccountStore(directoryOrGroup);
        Then, when authenticating an account, this AccountStore (directory or group) will be consulted if no others before it in the list found a matching account.
        Parameters:
        accountStore - the new AccountStore resource to add to the Application's AccountStoreMapping list.
        Returns:
        the newly created AccountStoreMapping instance.
        Throws:
        ResourceException
        Since:
        0.9

      • getApiKey

        ApiKey getApiKey(String id)
                 throws ResourceException,
                        IllegalArgumentException
        Gets an ApiKey, by its id, that belongs to an Account that has access to this application by a mapped account store.

        Parameters:
        id - the id of the ApiKey to be retrieved.
        Returns:
        an ApiKey, by its id, that belongs to an Account that has access to this application by a mapped account store.
        Throws:
        ResourceException - when the ApiKey does not belong to the Account or the ApiKey does not exist.
        IllegalArgumentException - if the id argument is null or empty.
        Since:
        1.0.RC

      • getApiKey

        ApiKey getApiKey(String id,
               ApiKeyOptions options)
                 throws ResourceException,
                        IllegalArgumentException
        Gets an ApiKey, by its id, that belongs to an Account that has access to this application by a mapped account store.

        A call to this method ensures that the returned ApiKey response reflects the specified ApiKeyOptions.

        Parameters:
        id - the id of the ApiKey to be retrieved.
        options - the ApiKeyOptions to use to customize the ApiKey resource upon retrieval.
        Returns:
        an ApiKey, by its id, that belongs to an Account that has access to this application by a mapped account store with the specified ApiKeyOptions.
        Throws:
        ResourceException - when the ApiKey does not belong to the Account or the ApiKey does not exist.
        IllegalArgumentException - if the id argument is null or empty, or if the options argument is null..
        Since:
        1.0.RC

      • authenticateApiRequest

        ApiAuthenticationResult authenticateApiRequest(Object httpRequest)
                                               throws IllegalArgumentException,
                                                      ResourceException
        Authenticates an HTTP request submitted to your application's API, returning a result that reflects the successfully authenticated Account that made the request and the ApiKey used to authenticate the request. Throws a ResourceException if the request cannot be authenticated.

        This method will automatically authenticate both HTTP Basic and OAuth 2 requests. However, if you require more specific or customized OAuth request processing, use the authenticateOauthRequest(Object) method instead; that method allows you to customize how an OAuth request is processed. For example, you will likely want to call authenticateOauthRequest(Object) for requests directed to your application's specific OAuth 2 token and authorization urls (often referenced as /oauth2/token and /oauth2/authorize in OAuth 2 documentation).

        Servlet Environment Example

        For example, if running in a Servlet environment: 

         //assume a request to, say, https://api.mycompany.com/foo:

 public void onApiRequest(HttpServletRequest request, HttpServletResponse response) {

    Application application = client.getResource(myApplicationRestUrl, Application.class);

    ApiAuthenticationResult result = application.authenticateApiRequest(request).execute();

    Account account = result.getAccount();

    // Check to see that account is allowed to make this request or not before processing
    // the request.  For example, by checking the account's groups or any of your own
    // application-specific permissions that might exist in the group's or account's customData.
    assertAuthorized(account); //implement the 'assertAuthorized' method yourself.

    //process request here
 }
        Depending on your application architecture, the above logic might be better suited in a Servlet Filter so your Servlets or MVC Controllers don't need to be 'aware' of OAuth logic.

        Non-Servlet Environment Example

        If your application does not run in a Servlet environment - for example, maybe you use a custom HTTP framework, or Netty, or Play!, you can use the HttpRequestBuilder to represent your framework-specific HTTP request object into a format the Stormpath SDK understands. For example:

         //assume a request to, say, https://api.mycompany.com/foo:

 public void onApiRequest(MyFrameworkHttpRequest request) {

    Application application = client.getResource(myApplicationRestUrl, Application.class);

    // Convert the framework-specific HTTP Request into a format the Stormpath SDK understands:
    HttpRequest request = HttpRequests.method(frameworkSpecificRequest.getMethod())
        .headers(frameworkSpecificRequest.getHeaders())
        .queryParameters(frameworkSpecificRequest.getQueryParameters())
        .build();

    ApiAuthenticationResult result = application.authenticateApiRequest(request).execute();

    Account account = result.getAccount();

    // Check to see that account is allowed to make this request or not before processing
    // the request.  For example, by checking the account's groups or any of your own
    // application-specific permissions that might exist in the group's or account's customData.
    assertAuthorized(account); //implement the 'assertAuthorized' method yourself.

    //process request here
 }

        OAuth 2 Example

        The above examples are generic - they assume either HTTP Basic or OAuth 2 authentication, and do not distinguish between the two. This is totally fine if that is suitable for your application.

        However, OAuth 2 also has the notion of scopes, also known as application-specific permissions. If the request is an OAuth 2 request, and you have previously assigned scopes to OAuth tokens you can check those scopes during an API request to control access.

        So how do we do that? How do we know if a request was a regular HTTP Basic request or an OAuth 2 request? We use an AuthenticationResultVisitor. This will allow us - in a compile-time/type-safe way to react to whatever is returned by the authenticate method. For example:

         //assume a request to, say, https://api.mycompany.com/foo:

 public void onApiRequest(HttpServletRequest /* or your framework-specific request - see above */ request) {

    Application application = client.getResource(myApplicationRestUrl, Application.class);

    ApiAuthenticationResult result = application.authenticateApiRequest(request).execute();

    final Set<String> scope = new LinkedHashSet<String>;

    result.accept(new AuthenticationResultVisitor() {

        @Override
        public void visit(ApiAuthenticationResult result) {
            //the request was a normal HTTP Basic request
        }

        @Override
        public void visit(OauthAuthenticationResult result) {
            //the request was authenticated using OAuth
            //ensure we can use the scopes for access control checks after this visitor returns:
            scope.addAll(result.getScope());
        }
        ...
    });

    Account account = result.getAccount();

    // Check to see that account is allowed to make this request or not before processing the request:
    // check the scope here for any permissions that are required for this API call.  You can also check
    // the account's groups or any of your own
    // application-specific permissions that might exist in the group's or account's customData.

    //process request here
 }

        Non Servlet Environments

        If your application does not run in a Servlet environment - for example, maybe you use a custom HTTP framework, or Netty, or Play!, you can use the HttpRequestBuilder to represent your framework-specific HTTP request object into a format the Stormpath SDK understands. You can then use example:

         ...
 // Convert the framework-specific HTTP Request into a format the Stormpath SDK understands:
    HttpRequest request = HttpRequests.method(frameworkSpecificRequest.getMethod())
        .headers(frameworkSpecificRequest.getHeaders())
        .queryParameters(frameworkSpecificRequest.getQueryParameters())
        .build();

    ApiAuthenticationResult result = application.authenticateApiRequest(request).execute();
 ...
        Parameters:
        httpRequest - either a javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest instance (if your app runs in a Servlet container) or a manually-constructed HttpRequest instance if it does not. An argument not of either type will throw an IllegalArgumentException.
        Returns:
        an ApiAuthenticationResult that represents the result of the authentication attempt.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the method argument is null or is not either a either a javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest or HttpRequest instance.
        ResourceException - if unable to authenticate the request
        Since:
        1.0.RC
        See Also:
        authenticateOauthRequest(Object)

      • authenticateOauthRequest

        OauthRequestAuthenticator authenticateOauthRequest(Object httpRequest)
                                                   throws IllegalArgumentException
        Authenticates an OAuth-based HTTP request submitted to your application's API, returning a result that reflects the successfully authenticated Account that made the request and the ApiKey used to authenticate the request. Throws a ResourceException if the request cannot be authenticated.

        This method is only useful if you know for sure the HTTP request is an Oauth-based request, and:

        • The request is authenticating with an Access Token and you want to explicitly control the locations in the request where you allow the access token to exist. If you're comfortable with the default behavior of inspecting the headers and request body (and not request params, as they can be seen as a less secure way of authentication), you do not need to call this method, and should call the authenticateApiRequest(Object) method instead.

        • The HTTP request is an OAuth Client Credentials Grant Type request whereby the client is explicitly asking for a new Access Token and you want to control the returned token's OAuth scope and/or time-to-live (TTL).

          This almost always is the case when the client is interacting with your OAuth token endpoint, for example, a URI like /oauth2/tokens. If the request is a normal OAuth request and this or the above condition does not apply to you, you do not need to call this method, and should call the authenticateApiRequest(Object) method instead.

        Again, if either of these two scenarios above does not apply to your use case, do not call this method; call the authenticateApiRequest(Object) method instead.

        Next, we'll cover these 2 scenarios.

        Scenario 1: OAuth (Bearer) Access Token Allowed Locations

        By default, this method and authenticateApiRequest(Object) will authenticate an OAuth request that presents its (bearer) Access Token in two of three locations in the request:

        1. The request's Authorization header, per the OAuth 2 Bearer Token specification, Section 2.1.
        2. The request application/x-www-form-urlencoded body as a access_token parameter, per the OAuth 2 Bearer Token specification, Section 2.2

        Although checking a request access_token query parameter, per the OAuth 2 Bearer Token specification, Section 2.3 is also supported, query parameters are NOT inspected by default. Using request parameters for authentication is often seen as a potential security risk and generally discouraged. That being said, if you need to support this location, perhaps because you need to support a legacy client, you can enable this location explicitly if desired, for example: 

         import static com.stormpath.sdk.oauth.RequestLocation.*;

 OAuthAuthenticationResult result = application.authenticateOauthRequest(httpRequest)
     .inLocation(HEADER, BODY, QUERY_PARAM)
     .execute();

        The above code example implies that you will tell developers which options they may use (and may not use) when configuring their OAuth client to communicate with your API.

        Scenario 2: Creating OAuth Access Tokens

        If the HTTP request is sent to your OAuth token creation endpoint, for example, /oauth2/token you will need to call this method, and the Stormpath SDK will automatically create an Access Token for you. After it is created, you must send the token to the client in the HTTP response. For example: 

         //assume a POST request to, say, https://api.mycompany.com/oauth/token:

 public void processOauthTokenRequest(HttpServletRequest request, HttpServletResponse response) {

    Application application = client.getResource(myApplicationRestUrl, Application.class);

    AccessTokenResult result = (AccessTokenResult) application.authenticateOauthRequest(request).execute();

    TokenResponse token = result.getTokenResponse();

    response.setStatus(HttpServletResponse.SC_OK);
    response.setContentType("application/json");
    response.getWriter().print(token.toJson());

    response.getWriter().flush();
 }

        As you can see, tokenResponse.toJson() method will return a JSON string to populate the response body - it is not strictly necessary to read individual properties on the TokenResponse instance.

        Non Servlet Environments

        If your application does not run in a Servlet environment - for example, maybe you use a custom HTTP framework, or Netty, or Play!, you can use the HttpRequestBuilder to represent your framework-specific HTTP request object as a type the Stormpath SDK understands. For example:

         ...
 // Convert the framework-specific HTTP Request into a request type the Stormpath SDK understands:
    HttpRequest request = HttpRequests.method(frameworkSpecificRequest.getMethod())
        .headers(frameworkSpecificRequest.getHeaders())
        .queryParameters(frameworkSpecificRequest.getQueryParameters())
        .build();

    ApiAuthenticationResult result = application.authenticateOauthRequest(request).execute();
 ...

        Customizing the OAuth Access Token Time-To-Live (TTL)

        By default, this SDK creates Access Tokens that are valid for 3600 seconds (1 hour). If you want to change this value, you will need to invoke the withTtl method on the returned executor and specify your desired TTL. For example: 

         //assume a POST request to, say, https://api.mycompany.com/oauth/token:

 public void processOauthTokenRequest(HttpServletRequest request, HttpServletResponse response) {

    Application application = client.getResource(myApplicationRestUrl, Application.class);

    int desiredTimeoutSeconds = 3600; //change to your preferred value

    AccessTokenResult result = (AccessTokenResult)application
        .authenticateOauthRequest(request)
        .withTtl(desiredTimeoutSeconds)
        .execute();

    TokenResponse token = result.getTokenResponse();

    response.setStatus(HttpServletResponse.SC_OK);
    response.setContentType("application/json");
    response.getWriter().print(token.toJson());

    response.getWriter().flush();
 }

        Customizing the OAuth Access Token Scope

        As an Authorization protocol, OAuth allows you to attach scope, aka application-specific permissions to an Access Token when it is created. You can check this scope on later requests and make authorization decisions to allow or deny the API request based on the granted scope.

        When an access token is created, you can specify your application's own custom scope by calling the withScope method on the returned executor. For example: 

         //assume a POST request to, say, https://api.mycompany.com/oauth/token:

 public void processOauthTokenRequest(HttpServletRequest request, HttpServletResponse response) {

    Application application = client.getResource(myApplicationRestUrl, Application.class);

    int desiredTimeoutSeconds = 3600; //change to your preferred value

    ScopeFactory scopeFactory = getScopeFactory(); //get your ScopeFactory implementation from your app config

    AccessTokenResult result = (AccessTokenResult)application
        .authenticateOauthRequest(request)
        .withTtl(desiredTimeoutSeconds)
        .withScopeFactory(scopeFactory)
        .execute();

    TokenResponse token = result.getTokenResponse();

    response.setStatus(HttpServletResponse.SC_OK);
    response.setContentType("application/json");
    response.getWriter().print(token.toJson());

    response.getWriter().flush();
 }

        Your ScopeFactory implementation can inspect the 1) successfully authenticated API client Account and 2) the client's requested scope. Your implementation returns the actual scope that you want granted to the Access Token (which may or may not be different than the requested scope based on your requirements).

        Parameters:
        httpRequest - either an javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest instance (if your app runs in a Servlet container or a manually-constructed HttpRequest instance if it does not.
        Returns:
        a new OauthRequestAuthenticator that acts as a builder to allow you to customize request processing behavior
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the method argument is null or is not either a either a javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest or HttpRequest instance.
        Since:
        1.0.RC
        See Also:
        authenticateApiRequest(Object)

      • newIdSiteUrlBuilder

        IdSiteUrlBuilder newIdSiteUrlBuilder()
        Creates a new IdSiteUrlBuilder that allows you to build a URL you can use to redirect your application users to a hosted login/registration/forgot-password site - what Stormpath calls an 'Identity Site' (or 'ID Site' for short) - for performing common user identity functionality. When the user is done (logging in, registering, etc), they will be redirected back to a callbackUri of your choice.

        This method is a complement to the newIdSiteCallbackHandler(Object) method: you use this newIdSiteUrlBuilder method to send the end-user to your ID Site. When the end-user is finished on the ID Site and they are returned to your application, you use the newIdSiteCallbackHandler(Object) method to process the result.

        Example

        Let's assume your application's end-users use a web browser to visit your web application at https://awesomeapp.com. When they login, you want to send them to something like https://my.awesomeapp.com or https://id.awesomeapp.com so you don't have to build all the login, registration, and forgot password screens from scratch.

        When your end-user clicks a 'login' link, you would redirect them to your ID Site. That link click request might be handled as follows:

         public void onLoginLinkClick(HttpServletRequest request, HttpServletResponse response) {

    Application application = client.getResource(myApplicationRestUrl, Application.class);

    //this is the fully qualified URL that your end-user should return to after they are finished at the
    // ID Site.  It is usually a URL in your web application, for example: https://awesomeapp.com/id
    // For security reasons, the callbackUri must equal a registered URI in the Stormpath Administration console
    String callbackUri = "https://awesomeapp.com/id";

    String redirectUrl = application.newIdSiteUrlBuilder().setCallbackUri(callbackUri).build();

    response.setHeader("Cache-Control", "no-store, no-cache, must-revalidate");
    response.addHeader("Cache-Control", "post-check=0, pre-check=0");
    response.setHeader("Pragma", "no-cache");

    //send a 302 redirect to your ID Site.  When they're done, they will return to your callbackUri:
    response.sendRedirect(redirectUrl);
 }

        When the end-user is done using your ID Site, they will be redirected back to your specified callbackUri. Requests submitted to your callbackUri should be handled via the newIdSiteCallbackHandler(Object) method.

        Returns:
        a new IdSiteUrlBuilder that allows you to build a URL you can use to redirect your application users to a hosted login/registration/forgot-password 'ID Site'.
        Since:
        1.0.RC2
        See Also:
        IdSiteUrlBuilder.setCallbackUri(String), IdSiteUrlBuilder.setPath(String), IdSiteUrlBuilder.setState(String)

      • newIdSiteCallbackHandler

        IdSiteCallbackHandler newIdSiteCallbackHandler(Object httpRequest)
        Creates a new IdSiteCallbackHandler used to handle HTTP replies from your ID Site to your application's callbackUri, as described in the newIdSiteUrlBuilder() method.

        This method should be called when processing an HTTP request sent by the ID Site to the callbackUri specified via the newIdSiteUrlBuilder() method.

        Example

        Assume that you previously newIdSiteUrlBuilder(), built the URL, and redirected your end-user to that URL. When the end-user is finished interacting with your ID Site, they will be redirected back to the callbackUri you specified when constructing the URL. You would call this method when processing the request to that callbackUri.

        For example, assume your callbackUri is https://awesomeapp.com/id and you process requests to that URI with a (sample) onIdSiteCallback method below:

         public void onIdSiteCallback(HttpServletRequest request, HttpServletResponse response) {

    Application application = client.getResource(myApplicationRestUrl, Application.class);

    AccountResult result = application.newIdSiteCallbackHandler(request).getAccountResult();

    //get the account that signed-up or logged in successfully:
    Account account = result.getAccount();

    //do whatever you want with the returned account :)

    // result.isNewAccount() == true for a newly registered user
    // result.isNewAccount() == false for an existing user that logged in

    // When you're done, you might want to redirect the end-user to a welcome page or
    // a 'my account' page, for example:
    response.sendRedirect("/myaccount");
 }
        Servlet Container or No Servlet Container?

        This method will accept either a javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest instance if your app is running in a Servlet container, or a manually-constructed HttpRequest instance if it is not. See the HttpRequests helper class to help build the request object if you are running in a non-servlet environment.

        Parameters:
        httpRequest - either an javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest instance (if your app runs in a Servlet container) or a manually-constructed HttpRequest instance if it does not.
        Returns:
        an IdSiteCallbackHandler that allows you customize how the httpRequest will be handled.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the method argument is null or is not either a either a javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest or HttpRequest instance.
        Since:
        1.0.RC2
        See Also:
        newIdSiteUrlBuilder(), HttpRequests, IdSiteCallbackHandler, IdSiteCallbackHandler.getAccountResult()
